description: Borrowed from Middle French emmurer, from Old French [Term?], from Latin immūrō, from in- + mūrus (“wall”).

verbs.description: immure (third-person singular simple present immures, present participle immuring, simple past and past participle immured)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To cloister, confine, imprison or hole up: to lock someone up or seclude oneself behind walls.
examples: The gentlemen looked at each other for a ſolution of this ſtrange event, each preſuming an order had been obtained to again immure the unfortunate Clara.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To put or bury within a wall.
examples: John's body was immured Thursday in the mausoleum.

entries.meaning: (transitive, crystallography and geology, of a growing crystal) To trap or capture (an impurity); chiefly in the participial adjective immured and gerund or gerundial noun immuring.
examples:
On increasing the supercooling, the step starts completely immuring the impurity and 
  
    
      
        v
      
    
    {\displaystyle v}
  
 rises sharply.
